Pre-norm vs Post-norm

12 Feb 2026

Let xℓx_\ellxℓ​﻿ be the hidden state entering layer ℓ\ellℓ﻿, and Fℓ(⋅)F_\ell(\cdot)Fℓ​(⋅)﻿ be a sublayer (attention or MLP).

Post-norm (original Transformer style)

Pre-norm (modern LLM default)

Why pre-norm stabilizes very deep models

It gives you a clean “identity gradient highway”

Back-propagation through the residual:

Pre-norm:

That +I+I+I﻿ is the big deal: even if the sublayer path is noisy/unstable early in training, gradients still have a near-identity route across many layers. So deep stacks don’t need every layer to be “well-behaved” from step 1.

Post-norm:

Now the gradient gets multiplicatively gated by the norm Jacobian JNormJ_{\mathrm{Norm}}JNorm​﻿ every layer. Over depth, products of these Jacobians can shrink or distort gradients (and they also couple dimensions). That makes very deep Transformers harder to optimize without careful tricks.

Norm is outside the residual path in pre-norm

In post-norm, the output is always normalized, which sounds nice, but it means the residual “skip” isn’t a true skip anymore — it’s always followed by a normalization transform. In pre-norm, the skip path is literally xℓ→xℓ+1x_\ell \to x_{\ell+1}xℓ​→xℓ+1​﻿ untouched, which improves signal/gradient propagation in deep networks.

Optimization early phase is easier

Empirically, post-norm often needs more delicate LR/warmup/init to avoid divergence as depth grows. Pre-norm is more forgiving, so it became the default for deep decoder-only LLMs.

Rule of thumb: the deeper the model, the more pre-norm tends to “just work”.
